While testing out Arvoreen's Silent Sting (Monk 21/Rogue 13/CoT 6), I thought about drawing up her antithesis: that is, where she's in and out of shadow, crippling and throwing multiple attacks out: what about someone who's just stuck in tar, shrugging and saying, "Not hard enough, idiot. Try again," ad infinitum? In other words a Dwarven Defender. So I had a look around and came across Grizzled Dwarflord's Hearth Guard (DwD 22/CoT 10/Fighter 8) in the legacy archive. That looked lovely, but I wondered about some of the feats, and have always liked being skilled in 2 different weapon types (in this instance, slashing and bludgeoning), so looked at a few minor tweaks - effectively, a new lick of paint and some varnishing. At that point, I ran into some questions. These are detailed below, together with the ensuing discussions. GDL's original build is also given in the SPOILER below, for comparative purposes.

Environmental issues

I have based my weapon choices predominantly what's readily available in Aielund (and what isn't, ie, Heavy Flail). Conversely, you won't find any Dwarven Waraxes in the OC, so you might find that WProf: Exotic is an unnecessary feat. In which case, go for Battleaxe and Heavy Flail (with its 1.5 damage) and take either Power Attack instead of Exotic WProf and then Cleave instead of the second Imp Crit, or just add in Disarm for use with your 2-hander. But you'll know what you can unearth and make good use of where you play. Equally, do feel free to swap Blind Fight and Knockdown around, and, if AC is your priority, switch Armor Skin with Epic Prowess. If taunting is an issue, the lack of Concentration may be an problem, but hey, only 129 SPs!

My initial queries fell into three categories: Feats, Saves and Skills.

Feats. Cleave (and by default, Power Attack) was something I realised I was missing, and if I'm right the Cleaving doesn't interrupt Defensive Stance, would I be a fool not to take it? Given that it's effectively 2 feats, I reckon Iron Will and IKD are the most vulnerable. What do you think? Another way to go that allows me to keep IKD would be to take Fighter 8 at level 20, but that would mean losing one bonus feat in epic - either AS or EP would be my guess. All these seem to have pluses and minuses - what does the Guild think?

Saves. I appear to have gone "save-blind". I did two sets of calculations on "straight" saves, and got F36/W27/R26 in one, and F37/W24/R22 in the other (both with my red changes implemented). Neither of which tallies with the Dwarflord's F36/W24/R24. Could you help, please?

Skills. Massively skill-starved (only 129 points). I thought I'd go with Conc 8 (14), Disc 43 (52), Spell 19 (20), Tumble 20 (21), but this leaves me with a big fat 0 in detection (Listen, Spot, or even Search). To some extent it bothers me less in this build - I don't plan to be sneaking after enemies, I shall be beckoning them to me (I like the company) - but I wondered whether I could get INT to 14 without collapsing the build. The only way I can see it is to drop CON to 21, which is all you need for EDRIII, and start it at 17. I could then move out a pre-epic STR boost to CON and take the final (level 40) boost as STR. That would also mean I could bump WIS by 2 at creation, upping Will saves by 1. However, it would also drop Fort by 1 and HPs by 40. Or should I just bite the bullet? Any thoughts?

Maybe this is all a bit anal of me, but I really would value your thoughts.

Btw, there were of course, other DwD builds out there that I looked at, but I really liked the underpinning principles of this one, and thought it deserved updating to v1.69. I hope this attempt achieves that.

Cheers

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Just first impressions before I head back to the job site...

I agree about Spot but disagree about Listen.  Neither are for sneaking but rather detecting sneakers. You need not hunt to find them.  They will find you. Figure on getting spammed by lots of sneak damage if you can't hear them approaching.  Spot will only help in the rare instance that you happen to chose to set up your combat stance directly in a nest of hiding rogues/assassins shoulder-to-shoulder.  It could happen, I suppose, but in PvM the AI will typically cause them to move towards you long before you get that close.  The exception would be hiding rogue archers which don't need to move and won't except to maintain LOS.  Hence, the benefit of maxing both detection skills... but melee sneakers in motion seems to be more prevalent than occasional ranged attacks to me.

Since your saves are very good anyway, my personal bias would induce me to take exotic for Dwarven Waraxe, the best 1H weapon available. Cost: Iron Will. Use Clarity (short term) and/or Owl pots (long term) for your Will concerns.

I'll try to check your bean-counting upon return.  I do like the build's main notion, though.  It looks like a worthwhile adjunct to GDL's version.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thanks, Hip.

I are a plank. I'd been using eyes (or ears) that merely saw (or heard) me being aware of foes earlier and therefore better positioned to attack, rather than "here come the rat-bastards, ready yourself." Offense rather defense (I even used NFL spelling), which kind of defeats the point of this build. And, given the option, I's always go Listen over Spot (I know there's a discussion about the various merits on another subforum). It does, however, leave me with a quandry - what to drop? My thinking is Spellcraft, given that I get natural Dwarven bonuses v Spells anyway. Iirc, Listen is governed by INT (though it could be WIS), so I could get to 43 (44 or 42, depending), which would drop Conc to 3 (9) - or I could take a little Lore for Conc and save a few bucks. After all, no decent taunt is going be saved by that level of Conc. Or mix and match is available, I suppose. I know what you say about archers, but I'd really hope for someone to help there (not necessarily looking for this to solo much).

I'd actually opted for Exotic Prof and Dwarven Waraxe initially, but it's such a flighty thing - you might never find one worth the having, or you might find eight and kick yourself - that I ended up going standard Battleaxe. Of course, if I was going for "best" weapons, scimitars and large flails spring to mind (I can see the debate starting now...), but I also fancied the idea of "proper" Dwarf weapons featuring. It irks somewhat to have a dwarf take another proficiency for a weapon that should seem like second nature, but rules is rules I suppose...

I know I tend towards high Will saves in particular. It's not just an Aielund thing, I hate being rendered useless, and - given my tendency to play meleers - Will failures tend to hit harder than others, so I try to counteract them if I can.

I eagerly await further analysis (RL permitting) - but am currently off to meet Deekin in a Gnoll-infested village with the Silent Sting.

Oh, and Grizzled Dwarflord gives a marvellous back-story for his build, if anyone wants to check it out, regardless of the build itself.

Cheers

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
I no longer play environments that have not been designed as "equal opportunity" play areas.  A pox on the designer that tries to steer me towards their own personal bias.  But I do acknowledge the paucity of the dwarf's best ally, generally-speaking.  If it's SP, I'll just populate them myself and recompile.  If it's a PW, I'll make a courteous suggestion that the admin begin to rethink their decision to exclude Dwarf Axes, and if unattended, leave permanently for another server that has less anti-dwarven prejudice.  Assuming I really desire to RP dwarf, that is. And I often do.

GDL's stats come out thus on the CBC:

AC, naked: 10 + 1dex +4tumble +2as = 17 (25 w/fplate, 28 w/fplate+tower) [+1 Dodge feat, last attacker]

Saves F/W/R: 36/24/24 (38/26/26 v spells, racial)

Apparently, GDL had the inconvenient habit of including Dodge's AC in his figures.  If nothing else, it made readers do the calculation for themselves. It's basically the same for Nature's Sense.  Both are situational combat adjustments to the intrinsic base.  One applies only to last attacker and the other according to the tileset where the combat takes place.  It's fine to publish those figures but they should be hilighted so as not to confuse comparisons.

The rest of his analysis concurs with the results of Kamiryn's calculator.

In that bygone era, there was a lot of fanfic showing up on builds.  RP was the new rage (because a great proportion of NWNers came from the PnP world during NWN's infancy) and it really helped to set the theme with an interesting background.

SoU is probably the closest balance to PnP that BioWare created.  Very stingy loot/resources and extremely challenging with strong reliance on hench ally.  My only issue is that it is so well made, I would have preferred that HotU follow the same path rather than become a power loot grab.  Yeah, well.  That's the reason for all the CC, eh?

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote:
About a comment you made, no matter how high your UMD is, it won't help you use weapons or armor that you are not proficient.with. UMD only helps you use things that you are restricted from by class, race, or alignment, and maybe gender, but I'm not sure about that.

 
It's just those three emulations that UMD checks against item cost.  However, a custom item could theoretically restrict all three categories (typically, it only restricts one) making the item extremely high in value, possibly beyond UMD's capacity (figuring maxed skill with SkF/ESkF & high CHA), with class emulations being the easiest to pass.  As you've already indicated, you still must pass the related proficiency before a UMD check is performed.  Gender restriction is not possible without special scripting and modified 2das since it cannot be assigned to an item using the toolset.

Hope everyone's well.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
My suggestion is to republish GDL's original version as a completed/tested Level 40 ECB contribution similar to what I posted for Mith's Hierophant of Velsharoon (which had gained some special interest within related discussions).

Then, in a subsequent post within the same topic, detail and explain the variant that you've found useful to meet your own goals, comparing key elements that might distinguish it from the original Hearth Guard with your reason(s) to depart from the template.  In that way, a build search would locate both builds, though GDL's version would be used to establish the particulars.

You can either manually backcheck all of the Hearth Guard stats to confirm their accuracy or run through the CBC (which is what I did for all 200+ completed builds myself).  If you find any errors in the original, make notations to that effect within the originator's build (I use red bolding to highlight things like this) but leave the original, posted information intact.

If you need help transposing from the legacy archive, let me know, Stagmeister.  It shouldn't involve very much effort beyond a standard cut 'n paste.

edit, 20170421:  GDL's original build has been added to the Level 40 subforum, Stagmeister.  Feel free to amend your variant to the topic whenever you feel it's been tested enough to work out the kinks and itemize the differences.
